query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 «Chi è costui che ’l nostro monte cerchia 2 prima che morte li abbia dato il volo, 3 e apre li occhi a sua voglia e coverchia?».
query.error: **English:** 1 "Who is this who circles our mountain 2 before death has given him flight, 3 and opens and closes his eyes at will?"
query.result: 1 "Hwa is ðes ðe ðisne munt besæceð 2 ær ðon ðe deað him ðone flyht forgeaf, 3 and his eagan on willan onluceð?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
4 «Non so chi sia, ma so ch’e’ non è solo; 5 domandal tu che più li t’avvicini, 6 e dolcemente, sì che parli, acco’lo».
query.error: **English:** 4 "I do not know who he is, but I know that he is not alone; 5 ask you who are closer to him, 6 and gently, so that he speaks, approach him."
**English:** 7 Thus two spirits, one leaning to the other, 8 were speaking of me there on my right; 9 then they turned their faces to speak to me,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 e disse l’uno: «O anima che fitta 11 nel corpo ancora inver’ lo ciel ten vai, 12 per carità ne consola e ne ditta
query.error: **English:** 10 and the one said: "O soul that, still imprisoned 11 in the body, are journeying toward heaven, 12 for charity, console us and tell us
query.result: 10 ða cwæð ðara oðer: "Eala ðu sawl ðe ðus fæste 11 on ðinum lichaman ðurh ðis lyft farest, 12 ðurh mildheortnesse ðu us gefrætwie and gecyðe

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 onde vieni e chi se’; ché tu ne fai 14 tanto maravigliar de la tua grazia, 15 quanto vuol cosa che non fu più mai».
query.error: **English:** 13 where you come from and who you are; for you make us 14 marvel greatly at your grace, 15 as much as a thing that was never seen before."
query.result: 13 hwanon ðu come and hwæt ðu sy; forðæm ðu ðus 14 wundorlice us on ðinum wlite wundrað, 15 swa ðing ðe næfre ær gesewen nære."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 E io: «Per mezza Toscana si spazia 17 un fiumicel che nasce in Falterona, 18 e cento miglia di corso nol sazia.
query.error: **English:** 16 And I: "Through the middle of Tuscany there flows 17 a little river that is born in Falterona, 18 and a course of a hundred miles does not satisfy it.
query.result: 16 And ic: "Þurh midde Tuscana ðær rint 17 ea lyttel wæter ðe on Falterona upsprincð, 18 and hundmila his rines ne benæcð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
19 Di sovr’ esso rech’ io questa persona: 20 dirvi ch’i’ sia, saria parlare indarno, 21 ché ’l nome mio ancor molto non suona».
query.error: **English:** 19 Concerning him I asked this person: 20 to tell you who I am would be to speak in vain, 21 for my name is not yet widely known.
query.result: 19 Be ðæm ic ða ðone mon ðus befrægn: 20 secgan ðe hwæt ic sy, ðæt wære ydel spræc, 21 forðæm min nama nys gyt ðæs mæres.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 «Se ben lo ’ntendimento tuo accarno 23 con lo ’ntelletto», allora mi rispuose 24 quei che diceva pria, «tu parli d’Arno».
query.error: **English:** 22 "If your understanding is well-fleshed out 23 with intellect," then he who spoke before replied to me, 24 "you are speaking of the Arno."
query.result: 22 "Gif ðin inwit ðæt wel oncnáweð 23 mid ðí andgite," ðá me andswarode, 24 se ðe ær spræc, "ðú spricst be Árne."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 E l’altro disse lui: «Perché nascose 26 questi il vocabol di quella riviera, 27 pur com’ om fa de l’orribili cose?».
query.error: **English:** 25 And the other said to him: "Why did 26 this one conceal the name of that river, 27 just as one does with horrible things?".
query.result: 25 And ða oðer him cwæð: "Hwi ðeos nama 26 ðære ea ðeos dearnunga hæfð, 27 swa man deð ðara ðinga ðe atelicu sind?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 infin là ’ve si rende per ristoro 35 di quel che ’l ciel de la marina asciuga, 36 ond’ hanno i fiumi ciò che va con loro,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 vertù così per nimica si fuga 38 da tutti come biscia, o per sventura 39 del luogo, o per mal uso che li fruga:
query.error: **English:** 37 virtue is so put to flight by its enemy 38 from all, like a snake, either through misfortune 39 of the place, or through evil habit that torments them:
query.result: 37 ðæt ðær swa mægð ðurh feond geflymed beon 38 fram eallum, swa næddre, oððe ðurh gesceaft 39 ðæs wæteres, oððe ðurh yfel gewuna ðe ðær folc tæleð:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
40 ond’ hanno sì mutata lor natura 41 li abitator de la misera valle, 42 che par che Circe li avesse in pastura.
query.error: **English:** 40 whence the inhabitants of the wretched valley 41 have so changed their nature, 42 that it seems as if Circe had them in her pasture.
query.result: 40 ðanon ða wæteres eardgiefan swa awende 41 heora gecynd, ðæt hit ðuhte ðæt Circe 42 hæfde ða folc on hire gewealde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Tra brutti porci, più degni di galle 44 che d’altro cibo fatto in uman uso, 45 dirizza prima il suo povero calle.
query.error: **English:** 43 Among the ugly hogs, more worthy of gall 44 than of other food made for human use, 45 he first directs his wretched path.
query.result: 43 Betwux ðam wælhreowum, ðe wæron ðæs wyrsan weorðe 44 ðonne ænig oder mete mannum geworht, 45 he ærest ongan his earme lif lædan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Botoli trova poi, venendo giuso, 47 ringhiosi più che non chiede lor possa, 48 e da lor disdegnosa torce il muso.
query.error: **English:** 46 He then finds Botoli coming down, 47 snarling more than their strength allows, 48 and he turns his snout away from them in disdain.
query.result: 46 Botolf he funde ða he ðær færinga 47 gramra grymlicor ðonne him God ude, 48 and him ða deorc deoful ðreatode.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
49 Vassi caggendo; e quant’ ella più ’ngrossa, 50 tanto più trova di can farsi lupi 51 la maladetta e sventurata fossa.
query.error: **English:** 49 It goes on falling; and the more it swells, 50 the more it finds wolves made from dogs 51 in the cursed and ill-starred pit.
query.result: 49 He gæð feallende; and swa he máre weorðeð, 50 swa he má findan mæg hunda to wulfum 51 on ðære awyrgdan and on ðære ungesæligan pytte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Discesa poi per più pelaghi cupi, 53 trova le volpi sì piene di froda, 54 che non temono ingegno che le occùpi.
query.error: **English:** 52 Then, descending through deeper seas, 53 he finds the foxes so full of fraud, 54 that they fear no cunning that might entrap them.
query.result: 52 Siððan he nyðer astah on nearwe geneahhe, 53 ðær he ða fyndas fand swiðe facenfulle, 54 ðe ðæs cræftes ne wændon ðe hine awergan mihte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 Né lascerò di dir perch’ altri m’oda; 56 e buon sarà costui, s’ancor s’ammenta 57 di ciò che vero spirto mi disnoda.
query.error: **English:** 55 Nor will I cease to tell it, so that others may hear me; 56 and this man will be fortunate, if he still remembers 57 what the true spirit reveals to me.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Io veggio tuo nepote che diventa 59 cacciator di quei lupi in su la riva 60 del fiero fiume, e tutti li sgomenta.
query.error: **English:** 58 I see your grandson who becomes 59 a hunter of those wolves on the bank 60 of the fierce river, and he routs them all.
query.result: 58 Ic geseo ðinne nefan ðe geweorðeð 59 hunta ðæra wulfa on ðære ea 60 ðæs reðan flodes, and ealle ða fordræfeð.

query.result: 70 swa ic ða oðre sawle geseah, ðe ðær 71 stod and hlyste, gedrefed weorðan 72 siððan ðe heo ða word onfeng.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Ma da che Dio in te vuol che traluca 80 tanto sua grazia, non ti sarò scarso; 81 però sappi ch’io fui Guido del Duca.
query.error: **English:** 79 But since God wills that His grace shine so brightly in you, 80 I will not be stingy with you; 81 therefore, know that I was Guido del Duca.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Fu il sangue mio d’invidia sì rïarso, 83 che se veduto avesse uom farsi lieto, 84 visto m’avresti di livore sparso.
query.error: **English:** 82 My blood was so inflamed with envy, 83 that if I had seen a man rejoicing, 84 you would have seen me drenched in lividness.
query.result: 82 Wæs min blod of andan swa reðe, 83 ðæt gif ic mon sceolde geseon blide, 84 ðu sceoldest me geseon lifre bewrigen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Di mia semente cotal paglia mieto; 86 o gente umana, perché poni ’l core 87 là ’v’ è mestier di consorte divieto?
query.error: **English:** 85 From my seed I reap such straw; 86 O human race, why do you set your heart 87 where a forbidden consort is needed?

query.error: **English:** 88 This is Rinier; this is the pride and honor 89 of the house of Calboli, where no one 90 has since been heir to his valor.
query.result: 88 Þes is Rinier; þes is se wuldor and se wurðmynt 89 ðæs huses of Calboli, ðær nænig 90 siððan weard his weorðscype yrfeweard.

94 ché dentro a questi termini è ripieno 95 di venenosi sterpi, sì che tardi 96 per coltivare omai verrebber meno.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 Ov’ è ’l buon Lizio e Arrigo Mainardi? 98 Pier Traversaro e Guido di Carpigna? 99 Oh Romagnuoli tornati in bastardi!
query.error: **English:** 97 Where is the good Lizio and Arrigo Mainardi? 98 Pier Traversaro and Guido di Carpigna? 99 Oh Romagnuols, turned back into bastards!
query.result: 97 Hwar is se gōda Lizio and Arrigo Mainardi? 98 Pier Traversaro and Guido di Carpigna? 99 Ēa Rōmagnuolas, gewend eft tō bastarde!

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Quando in Bologna un Fabbro si ralligna? 101 quando in Faenza un Bernardin di Fosco, 102 verga gentil di picciola gramigna?
query.error: **English:** 100 When in Bologna did a Fabbro rise again? 101 When in Faenza a Bernardin di Fosco, 102 a noble branch of a humble stock?
query.result: 100 Hwanne in Bononia ān Fabbro ārās? 101 Hwanne in Faenza ān Bernardin di Fosco, 102 æðele trēow lytles gærses?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Non ti maravigliar s’io piango, Tosco, 104 quando rimembro, con Guido da Prata, 105 Ugolin d’Azzo che vivette nosco,

query.result: 103 Ne wundrige ðē gif ic wēpe, Tuscān, 104 ðonne ic gemimne, mid Guido da Prata, 105 Ugolin d’Azzo ðe mid ūs leofode,

106 Federigo Tignoso e sua brigata, 107 la casa Traversara e li Anastagi 108 (e l’una gente e l’altra è diretata),

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
109 le donne e ’ cavalier, li affanni e li agi 110 che ne ’nvogliava amore e cortesia 111 là dove i cuor son fatti sì malvagi.
query.error: **English:** 109 the ladies and the knights, the hardships and the comforts 110 that love and courtesy inspired in us 111 there where hearts have become so wicked.
query.result: 109 ðā wīf and ðā cempan, ðā earfeðu and ðā ēaðu 110 ðe in ūs onstyrede lufu and geornfulnes 111 ðær ðā heortan sind geworden swā yfele.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 O Bretinoro, ché non fuggi via, 113 poi che gita se n’è la tua famiglia 114 e molta gente per non esser ria?
query.error: **English:** 112 O Bretinoro, why do you not flee away, 113 since your family has departed 114 and many people in order not to be wicked?
query.result: 112 Eala Bretanora, hwi ne fleoh ðu aweg, 113 siððan ðin mægð gewat aweg 114 and micel folc forðæm ðe hi ne woldon beon yfele?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Ben fa Bagnacaval, che non rifiglia; 116 e mal fa Castrocaro, e peggio Conio, 117 che di figliar tai conti più s’impiglia.
query.error: **English:** 115 Bagnacaval does well, that does not bear children; 116 and Castrocaro does badly, and Conio worse, 117 that strive to beget such counts.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Ben faranno i Pagan, da che ’l demonio 119 lor sen girà; ma non però che puro 120 già mai rimagna d’essi testimonio.
query.error: **English:** 118 The Pagans will do well, since the devil 119 turns away from them; but not so that pure 120 testimony of them ever remains.
query.result: 118 Wel dydon ða hæðenan, ða ðe ðe deofol 119 fram him gewende; ac na ðeah ðe ðær æfre 120 clæne gewitnes of him æfter wurde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
121 O Ugolin de’ Fantolin, sicuro 122 è ’l nome tuo, da che più non s’aspetta 123 chi far lo possa, tralignando, scuro.
query.result:
**English:**
121 O Ugolino de’ Fantolin, your name is secure, 122 since no one is expected to do it anymore, 123 degenerating, obscure.
**Old English:**
121 Eala Ugolino de’ Fantolin, ðin noma is trywe, 122 siððan nan man ne mæg ðæt gedon, 123 awendan, deorc.
(Note: The word "trywe" in Old English means "secure" or "firm.")

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Ma va via, Tosco, omai; ch’or mi diletta 125 troppo di pianger più che di parlare, 126 sì m’ha nostra ragion la mente stretta».
query.error: **English:** 124 But go now, Tuscan, for now it pleases me 125 more to weep than to speak, 126 so tightly has our conversation constricted my mind.
query.result: 124 Ac ga nu, ðu Toscan, heonon; forðæm me nu licað 125 mare to wepenne ðonne to sprecenne, 126 swa swiðe hafað ure spræc ðone mod befangen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Noi sapavam che quell’ anime care 128 ci sentivano andar; però, tacendo, 129 facëan noi del cammin confidare.
query.error: **English:** 127 We thought that those dear souls 128 heard us walking; therefore, being silent, 129 they made us confident of the path.
query.result: 127 We wendon ðæt ða wlitegan sawla 128 usic gehyrdon gangan; forðæm ða, ða we ða swugode, 129 ða trymedon ða us ðæs weges.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Poi fummo fatti soli procedendo, 131 folgore parve quando l’aere fende, 132 voce che giunse di contra dicendo:
query.error: **English:** 130 Then we were made alone, proceeding, 131 a thunderbolt seemed to split the air, 132 a voice came from the opposite direction saying:
query.result: 130 Þa wæron we sylfe forðgongende, 131 liget swilce ðonne lyft gewiteð, 132 stefn of ðære gegnunge cwæð:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
133 ‘Anciderammi qualunque m’apprende’; 134 e fuggì come tuon che si dilegua, 135 se sùbito la nuvola scoscende.
query.error: **English:** 133 ‘Whoever catches me will kill me’; 134 and it fled like thunder that fades away, 135 if suddenly the cloud bursts.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
136 Come da lei l’udir nostro ebbe triegua, 137 ed ecco l’altra con sì gran fracasso, 138 che somigliò tonar che tosto segua:
query.error: **English:** 136 As our hearing had a respite from her, 137 behold, the other one with such a great crash, 138 that it resembled thunder that quickly follows:
query.result: 136 Swa swa ure hlyst fram hyre hæfde rest, 137 and ða ða oðer mid swylcum gedrefe, 138 ðæt hit geleceð ðunor ðe ðærrihte fylgeð:

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
139 «Io sono Aglauro che divenni sasso»; 140 e allor, per ristrignermi al poeta, 141 in destro feci, e non innanzi, il passo.
query.error: **English:** 139 "I am Aglauros who became stone"; 140 and then, in order to draw closer to the poet, 141 I took a step to the right, and not before.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Già era l’aura d’ogne parte queta; 143 ed el mi disse: «Quel fu ’l duro camo 144 che dovria l’uom tener dentro a sua meta.
query.error: **English:** 142 Now the air was still on every side; 143 and he said to me: "That was the hard curb 144 which should hold man within his boundary.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
145 Ma voi prendete l’esca, sì che l’amo 146 de l’antico avversaro a sé vi tira; 147 e però poco val freno o richiamo.
query.error: **English:** 145 But you take the bait, so that the hook 146 of the ancient adversary draws you to itself; 147 and therefore bridle or recall avails little.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.

query.error: **English:** 148 He calls to you from heaven and circles around you, 149 showing you his eternal beauties, 150 and your eye looks only at the ground;

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
151 onde vi batte chi tutto discerne».
query.error: **English:** 151 therefore he beats you who discerns all things.
query.result: 151 forðæm ðe beoð ðe ða geswincðe
